title: sadiq khan rent control london mayor
story: As he launched his bid for re-election as Mayor of London, the Labour bigwig demanded rent controls.He insisted the move would help renters by reducing their outgoing and allowing them to stay in their homes.But critics claimed it would end up wrecking the housing market - and questioned when Mr Khan can actually make it happen anyway.Rent controls would be illegal unless backed up by a law passed in Parliament.But Mr Khan told thehes drawing up a blueprint to demonstrate how the measure could work.He said: London is in the middle of a desperate housing crisis that has been generations in the making.“I am doing everything in my power to tackle it – including building record numbers of new social homes – but I have long been frustrated by my lack of powers to help private renters.Shaun Bailey, the Mayors Tory rival for the  election, dismissed the idea Mr Khan can achieve rent controls by himself.A spokesman told The Sun: Londoners wont be fooled.Why anyone would trust Sadiq to deliver something he cant deliver when he cant deliver the things he can deliver - like turning the £.billion hes been given for housing into homes - is beyond us.Most private rents in Britain used to be capped so they couldnt be hiked year on year.But regulations on rent rises were scrapped by Margaret Thatcher in the s.Most economists claim the measure reduces the housing supply, which drives up prices in the long run.Matthew Lesh of the free-market Adam Smith Institute said: There are fewer more stupid ideas. Every time rent control has been tried, in every place, it has had disastrous consequences.Rent control will make London’s housing crisis worse by decreasing the availability and quality of housing.Its not backed by a single competent economist and Londons mayor shows hes not serious by suggesting such an economically illiterate policy.Polls show that most renters back the policy and believe it would help ease the housing crisis.

title: brexit mess political party rod liddle opinion
story: So I tell you what — let’s have a party.Thing is, I don’t mean a shindig where we all get copiously rat-a***d.I mean a political party. A new political party, which represents what a lot of us want.Because you’ve got to say — the parties in Westminster aren’t doing that, are they Whatever happens at the end of this awful Brexit mess, one thing is clear, our politics have to change.The isions between our current parties no longer reflect the isions in the country. If Brexit has told us anything, it’s told us that.And there is a growing anger out there that the views of millions and millions of people are simply not represented in Parliament.That’s obvious from Brexit — more than a third of Labour voters wanted us to leave. Including a majority in some northern constituencies. Almost two thirds of Tory voters wanted us to leave.Nigel Farage, the former leader of Ukip, has already said he fancies creating a new party. A Brexit Party.Good luck to the man — I might even join it, because I have the horrible feeling our Parliament is going to betray the people, and we’ll end up staying in. That would be a travesty of democracy.The very reasons which convinced more than million of us to vote for Brexit were the same as those which are causing isions across Europe. And as a result we’ve seen the huge rise of populist parties. In Italy, Hungary, Poland, Slovakia, Greece, France and even Germany. Oh — and, of course — the USA.These parties are sometimes right wing, sometimes left wing. In Italy there is an alliance between the two.What they are all, though, is dferent to the politics we have now. They are parties which listen to the people. Populist is just another way of saying popular, really.Most agree on a whole bunch of issues. We need to control immigration, number one. Especially immigration from Islamic countries.We need a bit more respect for the nation state: People feel proud of the countries in which they live. Yes, even some Belgians.A lot are socially conservative. By which I mean they do not have much time for gender neutral toilets, LGBTQI protests, political correctness and so on.Instead, they have a respect for traditional values. For the family, for the Christian faith, on which our countries were founded. For our histories. And they are sceptical of the European Union.But they also recognise that there are deep economic isions within our countries which need to be addressed. In our own country a terrible chasm between the affluence and influence of London, versus the rest of the country. Between rich and poor.We have no political party right now which covers those bases.But that is where the real ide in society lies. So, as January drags on — how about a party  One that represents US Labour MP Diane Abbott thinks that the BBC Question Time programme discriminated against her because she is:a blackAbbott got a rough ride and the audience spent most of the time laughing at her or booing.Diane, listen. It’s not your skin colour. It’s not your gender.It’s something  altogether.We are used to politicians speaking down to us.And we are used to politicians being thick.But when both occur at the same time, that’s when the rest of us decide we’ve had enough.Stuff the BBC won’t tell you.Number One – The International Monetary Fund has admitted it got its projections wrong.The UK economy is not stagnating. Economic growth for the next year will be every bit as strong as in France and Germany.And meanwhile all the other indicators – investment, employment, growth in wages – are MUCH better than those in the European Union.Someone tell Huw Edwards.Yet again I’ve accepted a Facebook friend request from a woman without checkingshe’s a proper woman, rather than a porno sock-puppet.Sure enough, within the minute, I was invited to view intimate photographs of the lady.And she ended her invitation with the words: “Slap my frog, cowboy!”Why would I want to slap her frog  I hope her frog has a long and happy le. And why am I a cowboyTheres nothing funnier than slebs making idiots of themselves while politically grandstanding.Gary Lineker, for example, does it every week. His intellect is about as radiant as a candle flame in an aircraft hangar. But he still gives it large, ranting about Brexit. And praising Europe’s worst leader, France’s Emmanuel Macron.The latest slebs to fall foul are the Spice Girls. They posed for photos in “edgy”T-shirts reading: Gender Justice. Now it’s been revealed those shirts were made in a workshop by women who are paid p per hour.There’s gender justice for you.The memorial to Bomber Command in London’s Hyde Park has been defaced by scumbags.They threw paint over the sculpture – and also vandalised statues of Winston Churchill and US President Franklin D. Roosevelt.Our pilots in World War Two won a battle against all the odds to protect this country from fascism. More than , of them died doing so.The filth who vandalised the memorial know nothing of that. Nothing of personal sacrice, of hardship, of discipline.And they know nothing of history, full stop.What kind of people are we raising in this country So, huge congratulations to Ant McPartlin.The perpetually smirking Geordie munchkin won “best presenter” at the National Television Awards, despite not having been on television for a year.People have criticised the decision, but I’m all in favour.Andhe promises to stay off the screens for another  months, I’d give him next year’s award, tooDid you see the shots of the babes turning up for the National Television Awards I call them babes because it was minus ten or something out there. title: bank chiefs deal save free cash
story: Link, the UK’s largest ATM network, said operators were being offered bigger support payments to keep “at risk” machines running in remote areas of the country.Link chief John Howells said: “It is vital we continue to provide free access to cash to those who need it.”He added: “As an additional benefit Link also expects a number of existing pay-to-use machines to be turned to free to use given the increased money available to operators of these machines.”The move was hailed by Frank Field, the campaigning opposition MP, who launched a Rip Off Britain campaign with The Sun in  blasting banks for charging people to withdraw their cash.He claimed more than , of Britain’s poorest people lived at least  kilometre from their nearest free-to-use ATM.Speaking yesterday, Mr Field said: “I think it’s the most important victory we have had since the start of the campaign.“We are now on the front foot and need to make sure banks ensure that eventually every cash machine is free.”Currently operators of ATMs more than km away from the nearest free to use ATM receive a subsidy of up to p per withdrawal to keep a lid on charges.But Link is increasing the subsidy to as much as £..The move follows outrage of ATM closures across the country.Last year Which  claimed  cash machines were closing a month.The consumer organisation’s Jenni Allen said: “Boosting premiums for remote machines has so far not been enough to stop cashpoints closing around the country, including in more remote areas where they are desperately needed.“We hope this latest move from Link is enough to arrest this alarming trend.“What is urgently needed is for a regulator to be given a duty to protect access to cash, so that the millions of people who rely on it in their lives are protected from rapid changes through ATM and bank branch closures.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may smear test women
story: Theresa May was asked to back the le-saving tests during PMQs to protect other women from developing cervical cancer.Mrs May said she understood the tests could be uncomfortable and even painful but called on all women to make sure they took up the offer of a test.She said: I, as a Prime Minister, can stand here and say this - I know what its like to go through a cervical smear test.It is not comfortable. title: sheikh mohammed bin rashid al maktoum fence longcross surrey
story: Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum ordered guards to build the prison fence without planning permission in Longcross, Surrey.The billionaire racehorse owner was accused of damaging the environment, while treating neighbours with contempt.In an objection to the Sheikhs retrospective request, neighbour Tom Barr said: Firstly, the applicant claims a .m fence height - yet it is in fact . m high by the applicants own dimensioned drawing.The applicant has shown a cynical disregard and contempt for planning procedures.It is visually intrusive and, aside from mostly being powder coated green, more suited to a prison or a factory boundary, rather than the boundary of a SSSI.Another described the development as a concentration camp which wasnt in keeping with the landscape.It blocks vital corridors of hedges and tree lines which endangered Dartford Warblers and other birds use.Rare creatures like dormice also use these corridors to travel across the countryside between Chobham Common and the previously-open estate, added the neighbour.It is highly puzzling that he did not apply for permission before all this came to light, the neighbour went on.The fences should be removed immediately to mitigate the damage to wildle.Prior to the construction of the fence, the estates boundary was marked by lower, wooden fence posts or, in some places, no fence at all.The ruler of Dubais land is covered by an Article  Declaration, meaning even minor changes must receive permission from the council.Security at the estate was already tight, with perimeter guards, CCTV and an inner security fence.But in  one of the Sheikhs daughters, Shiekha Shamsa al-Maktoum, then , escaped the estate on to Chobham Common.One of her younger sisters, Sheikha Lata, claimed in March  that Sheikha Shamsa was being kept in a drugged state in the Zabeel Palace in Dubai and was like a zombie.Sheikha Lata, , made the claim in a video that she sent to human rights organisation Detained in Dubai before saying she had attempted to escape her father herself.The bid, the subject of a BBC documentary aired on December th, was thwarted when the boat on which she was travelling was intercepted in the Indian Ocean by UAE and Indian naval vessels.She has not been seen since, but her family claim she is safe in Dubai.The Longcross estate is just part of a vast property portfolio controlled by Sheikh Mohammed, who is believed to have a personal fortune in excess of £ billion.It is thought the - year-old, who is both vice-president and prime minister of the United Arab Emirates, will seek retrospective planning permission.Runnymede council and Dubai’s government failed to provide a comment.

title: now tv hiring box set binger favourite shows

title: ghost monk dudley castle
story: Helen Wakeman, , and her partner John Dargan, , were on a paranormal investigations tour at Dudley Castle, West Mids, earlier this month.The couple, from Birmingham, were left speechless when they checked their pictures from the trip later on to discover the spooky apparition.Helen took the picture as John stood on the steps that lead to the castle but says she never noticed the figure stood to the right of the archway.Later the pair were told by a tour guide that monks would have often walked through the archway to attend prayers at the castle.Helen said: My parents bought me and John the tickets for the tour as a Christmas present as we had done a few before and got the bug for it.We have become avid ghost hunters and get a real thrill out of it but have never managed to capture anything on camera until now.We had just started the tour, on a car park close to the steps, and only took it as a quick photo, we never even looked at it till a few days later.We had a great night, it was very spooky and we went off in groups for vigils and to explore the grounds.When we finally looked through the pictures we had taken we spotted the figure next to the archway, which eerily looks like a monk with a hooded cloak.We were so excited that we had finally managed to capture something on camera.Dudley Castle, which dates back to , has been regarded as one of the most haunted in the UK and the legend of the Grey Lady has been around for centuries, with multiple sighting of the fabled spook.According to legend the Grey Lady is the spirit of a woman called Dorothy Beaumont who died shortly after childbirth, along with her child. She wanted to buried next to her child, but her wish was never granted and so she haunts the castle grounds.Helen said: We were the first couple to walk up the steps so there was no one in front of us.It was a quick memory snap and we werent expecting it to happen so early on in the tour.The tour guide told us that monks from the nearby priory would have walked up the steps towards the castle for prayers and lessons and the shape look similar to a habit.We were very freaked out.Amy Harper, , from Birmingham, West Mids, snapped a selection of pictures while visiting in  and claimed to have snapped a ghostly figure of a woman in one of the archways.

title: peta slammed for sick stunt barbecuing a dog in sydney street leaving young kids in tears
story: Shoppers and their children were traumatised by the realistic bloody prop being grilled whole at a shopping centre in Sydney.Peta activists set up the sick stunt with a banner that read: “If You Wouldn’t Eat a Dog, Why Eat a Lamb  Go Vegan!”The groups aim was to raise awareness for the idea that dogs are “no dferent to lamb, cows or chicken”.Some outraged onlookers took to Twitter to express their disgust in PETAs shocking stunt.One Twitter user wrote: @peta stopping to new lows with their stunt in Martin Place today - terrying children on school holiday outings by barbecuing adog. I saw some visibly upset kidsAnother wrote: That supposed protest in Sydney is more inhumane than any slaughtering of animals. Keep them out of public places. It should be classed as public nuisance! Kids around  That is further reason to stop this! Exposing them to this    Cruel.Another angry bystander wrote: If you care for children, try not damaging them for the rest of their le. Your display was disgusting.The Government should introduce VLAD laws on the Extreme Vegan Protesters!! No more disturbing scenes and no heavy handed tactics on Meat focused restaurants.While another added: If you care about people stop showing them a very le like dog being barbecued. No one needs to see that.And before you say a dog is no dferent from a lamb maybe to you guys they arent dferent but to kids walking by they are very dferent.However, Peta’s Emily Rice told news.au the demonstration was “thought-provoking”.She said: “It’s not gruesome but it’s no dferent to when you’d walk past a Peking duck hanging in a shop window or a pig on a spit at a wedding.Since the controversial ordeal, Peta has been forced to defend themselves for its unorthodox demonstration.Rice said the organisation was used to receiving mixed reactions.She said: “It’s always mixed, it can be confronting to challenge what people think of as normal and it will be an emotionally charged day butwe manage to plant some seeds and start a conversation about speciesism then that’s a good thing.“We want people to think about why they’re happy to love one animal but eat another.”During the protest today, the organisation tweeted: “If you care about animals, try not eating them.”The organisation said in a statement: The idea of barbecuing dogs rightly causes outrage amongst Australians.Meanwhile, millions of other equally sensitive and intelligent animals are forced to endure horric suffering when theyre bred, raised and killed for the meat industry.Anyone whos repulsed by the prospect of chowing down on dog meat should question the incongruity of their compassion towards other animals.The demonstration took place in Pitt Street because it is considered to host Sydneys busiest shopping centre.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum 32 suing thomas cook holiday waterslide
story: Jemma Joslyn, , has slammed the holiday giant after a woman crashed into her feet first while travelling “around  miles per hour”.The mother of two had been on holiday in Turkey for barely  hours when she was rushed to the hospital with internal bleeding, liver and kidney damage, fluid on the right lung and five cracked ribs.Jemma was terried her injuries would leave her on dialysis for the rest of her le as she had previously donated one of her healthy kidneys to her mum in .And she believes she would have diedher friends Natasha Gander,  and Bill Andrews, , hadnt been there to save her.She alleges staff at the Liberty Hotels Lykia did not check on who was caring for her children while she spent eight days in hospital, including three in the intensive care unit.The health care assistant, who had splashed out £, for the fortnight-long all-inclusive holiday, said: “I told my daughter to count to ten before coming down the slide, once I had gone down.“The woman came hurtling down the slide as I was just standing up to get out. I would say she was easily travelling at around  miles per hour.“But as soon as I stood up and turned around, I just saw this woman come hurtling towards me.“The impact sent me flying backwards into the water and I instantly started panicking that she had come down after my daughter and crushed her at the bottom.“The pain was excruciating and my eyes were just rolling back in my head.”The mum from Seaford, East Sussex, was rushed to the nearest hospital after slipping in and out of consciousness.Jemma claims she was then told her insurance didnt cover the hospital care as she had been taken to a private hospital.She later found out thatshe was taken to the nearest state hospital, which was two hours away, she would have died.Jemma, who still hasn’t been able toto work, said she felt like she was in an episode of Casualty with all of her injuries.She alleged: “If it was left up to Thomas Cook I would be dead and my children would be in the Turkish care system somewhere.”Recalling the nightmare visit, she said: “As soon as I got there, they gave me an emergency CT scan and it showed I had internal bleeding and my liver had a cm laceration.“It also showed that my kidney had been damaged. It was terrying, I thought I was facing a le on dialysis.“The doctors did another scan to compare and within ten minutes the amount of internal bleeding had doubled. The translator explained that they had to get me into theatre there and then.”Her parents flew to Turkey on an emergency flight to take care of their grandchildren while she underwent lesaving surgery, but claims that the holiday giant offered no extra support to her mum and dad to get to Turkey.Magdalena Knez, a travel litigation solicitor who is representing Jemma, said: “My client could have spent her le needing serious medical attention due to the fact that the swimming pool slide was not operated with the appropriate safety measures.“At this point we are still unclear as to the extent of her injuries and the long term effect this will have on her health.“Every British holiday maker has the right to be protected by their holiday provider who should provide adequate care while they are abroad.”She added: Thomas Cook have confirmed they have received our correspondence and are looking into the case.Thomas Cook has denied any liability.

title: venezuela iran hostage us diplomats maduro
story: The Trump administration has warned it will take “appropriate actions”any American citizens are endangered during the ongoing turmoil in the country.US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called on Venezuela’s military to protect its citizens after strongman President Maduro called for US diplomats to get out.Violent protests have erupted in the country leaving at least seven dead after thousands took to the streets in a bid to oust Maduro.The Marxist leader’s five-year reign looks set to be over after US-backed rival Juan Guaidó swore himself in as interim president to challenge the feared strongman.But after President Trump confirmed that Washington now recognised Guaidó as the oil-rich country’s new leader – Maduro hit back cutting diplomatic ties with the “imperialist US government.”He gave US diplomats  hours to leave Venezuela.This stand-off over US diplomats has sparked fears of a hostage crisis similar to the seige in  following the Iranian revolution which lasted for  days.The Iranian crisis, subject of the Oscar-winning movie Argo, involved  American diplomats being held hostage by the countrys new Islamic fundamentalist regime which had deposed the US-lacked leader Mohammad Reza Shah.The siege was the new regimes response to President Carter’s administration allowing its former leader to seek refuge in America.In Venezuela, it is still unclear what action strongman leader Maduro will take following the US diplomats refusal to leave the country.In front of a crowd of red-shirted protestors outside the Presidential palace, he said: “Dont trust the gringos.”Maduro rattled off a number of “gringo interventions” during the th Century – referencing the US backed military coups in Guatemala, Chile, BrazilHe added: They dont have friends or loyalties. They only have interests, guts and the ambition to take Venezuelas oil, gas and gold.Guaido issued a rival statement urging foreign embassies to ignore Maduro’s threats and keep their diplomats in the country.A few hours later, Pompeo confirmed the US would ignore Maduro’s threats to withdraw their embassy staff.The Secretary of State warned the “the Venezuelan military and security forces” against attempting to force US diplomats to leave the country.He warned America would take “appropriate action”US nationals were “endangered.”Pompeo said: “The United States will take appropriate actions to hold accountable anyone who endangers the safety and security of our mission and its personnel.”Trump branded Maduro’s government “illegitimate” and said that America stands with Venezuela.Maduro destroyed the oil-rich South American nation’s economy sparking rampant inflation which wrecked its health system and left his people starving.Charismatic Guaidó - a -year-old lawmaker scarred by rubber bullets in street demos - has boosted stalled efforts to finally oust limpet-like Maduro, .He has also won the crucial support of neighbouring nations Brazil and Colombia and Donald Trump’s US.The march and further unrest in the capital, Caracas followed two nights of violent protests in working-class neighbourhoods of Caracas where Maduro support was once firm.Other protests were planned across the country and outside embassies around the world.Guaidó warned notoriously brutal Maduro: “The world’s eyes are on our homeland today.”Guaidó - head of the countrys National Assembly - earlier described the president as a “usurper” and declared himself ready to assume the presidency until fair elections.He went on to bravely call on armed forces keeping Maduro in power to disobey the government.Venezuela - whose hard-left regime was saluted by Jeremy Corbyn in  - sits on the biggest oil reserves on earth.But its rulers have presided over rampant hyperinflation rendering the Boli currency worthless and sparked food and medicine shortages while crime rocketed.Street unrest boiled over amid spiralling economic turmoil after three million Venezuelans fled triggering a refugee crisis across the continent.

title: emiliano sala search team respond to reports of distress flare on tiny puffin reserve island
story: Footballer Sala, , is feared dead after his small private plane went off radar over the English Channel on Monday night.Rescue teams investigated reports of a “flare” near Burhou Island – a puffin reserve in the Channel.Pictures circulated on social media showed plumes of smoke from the tiny island, with some suggesting it was from the aces stricken aircraft.A Channel Islands Air Search aircraft spokeswoman said: During the search, reports of sightings of red flares were relayed by Guernsey Coastguard near to the island of Burhou, however nothing of signicance was found.Search boss John Fitzgerald explained to Wales Online: The plane and helicopters have been over many times since Monday night, but they havent seen anything in that area.It is only a few hundred metres long and it has been saturated by helicopters and fixed wing aircraft.We are airborne at the moment searching in that area. The flares I have seen pictures of are most likely aircraft trails.At .pm today, Guernsey Police tweeted: The island of Burhou has been searched by foot. No trace of the aircraft or those on board has been found.Salas plane vanished at around .pm on Monday, with aviation experts claiming ice on the wings could have caused it to crash into the Channel.The footie ace sent WhatsApp messages to his friends as the plane lurched in rough conditions, saying the plane “looks like it’s going to fall apart”.It was revealed Sala’s booking was made by the son of Scottish footie agent Willie McKay — although he was not involved in the Cardf transfer.Neither McKay nor his son Mark owned the aircraft.Meanwhile, underwear model Berenice Schkair, , who had been linked to Sala, wrote on Twitter: “Investigate the football mafia because I don’t believe this was an accident.”

title: brexit news latest theresa may eu exit delayed
story: No has concluded that ministers are unable to block an amendment tabled by Yvette Cooper which takes No Deal off the table.But they are fighting back by supporting a last-ditch bid to fix the hated Irish backstop.Today Theresa May is hosting union bosses in Downing Street and asking them to help her get her Brexit deal over the line.It comes before Tuesdays crunch vote where MPs will get a chance to vote on the way forward.A bumper  motions have been tabled by MPs keen to secure their favoured outcome.The most likely to succeed was tabled by Labours Ms Cooper and Tory Nick Boles.It says thatBritain is on course for a No Deal Brexit, Article  - the legal mechanism taking us out of the EU - should be suspended for as long as nine months.Labour are very likely to back the measure - although the delay could be cut to three months.A No source told the Daily Mail: It’s massively unhelpful. We’d have a week to try to persuade the Commons not to back the bill or Brexit would be delayed and the pressure would come off the EU.The pound soared yesterday on rising hopes that Brexit will end up being postponed.Senior Downing Street officials are currently trying to work out a way to ignore the amendmentit does pass.No is expected to back an alternative amendment, tabled by Tory Brexiteer Andrew Murrison, which deals with the Irish backstop.Brexit-supporting MPs want to impose a time limit on the backstop to avoid Britain being trapped in the EU customs union indefinitely.The Murrison motion is supported by Tory grandees from all sides of the Brexit spectrum, including Sir Nicholas Soames, Sir Graham Brady and Damian Green.A source close to Mrs May said she wants to see MPs vote for it next week.That would give her the ammunition she needs toto Brussels and request a legally binding change to the backstop.PM Leo Varadkar said: In order to honour our commitment to the people of Ireland that there be no hard border, we would have to agree on full alignment on customs and regulations.And his deputy Simon Coveney claimed keeping the UK in the customs union is the only way to uphold the Good Friday Agreement.He wrote in the : We will continue to require solutions to avoid a hard border that are rooted in regulatory alignment and legal certainty and not just wishful thinking.The backstop - intended to keep the Irish border open - has been roundly rejected by Brexiteers.And the UK Government is adamant that it can only be acceptableits time limited.Irish police have reportedly drawn up plans to send  police to the border in case of a No Deal outcome.This week the EU admitted for the first time that it will enforce a hard border on IrelandBritain leaves without a deal.Matt Hancock said today: The thing is that Parliament needs to come together and approve a deal to stop No Deal Brexit, and so far that hasnt happened.The EUs Brexit envoy Michel Barnier warned that a delay wouldnt be enough to ensure that both sides can reach a deal.He said: I personally believe that we do not need so much more time, but that we now need to make decisions.Today the PM has been hosting trade union chiefs at No in a bid to get more support for her deal.But Frances OGrady, general secretary of the TUC, said after her meeting: The Prime Minister hasnt given us the guarantees we need on jobs or workers rights.Even after a catastrophic defeat, her red lines havent shted, and the threat of No Deal hasnt even been taken off the table.Dave Prentis of Unison added: It is in everyones interest to extend Article  until at least the summer. We want Theresa May to move away from appeasing the right wing of the Tory party.NEXT Tuesday, the Commons will debate Theresa Mays Plan B for Brexit - which is identical to her Plan A.Although the debate will be on a so-called neutral motion, stating only that the Commons has considered her statement, MPs will have the power to table amendments dictating what should happen next.Speaker John Bercow - known for his pro-EU sympathies - will choose which ones MPs can vote on.COOPER - NINE-MONTH DELAYYvette Cooper is tabling a bill to stop Britain leaving the EU without a deal on March .She proposes thatthere isnt a deal by February , MPs could delay Article  for nine months - giving ministers until the end of the  to secure a withdrawal agreement.The bill is a standalone law, but an amendment to the PMs statement would see it catapulted to the top of the Commons agenda.Jeremy Corbyn is likely to support the move, which would give it a good chance of passing.GRIEVE - WRECKING BREXITDominic Grieve has proposed an amendment which would effectively transfer power from the Government to the Commons.Under the terms of his proposal, MPs would get the power to decide which bills are debated in Parliament, a privilege usually held by ministers.The amendment would tear up centuries of precedent by limiting the Governments ability to govern and so is unlikely to succeed.MURRISON - PMS LIFELINETory Brexiteer Andrew Murrison has an amendment which could help the PM make her case in Brussels.It takes the form of a demand for a time limit on the hated Irish backstop plan, to stop Britain being trapped in the EU customs union permanently.If Conservative backbenchers support it, Mrs May could then use that as proof that all she needs to get the deal through Parliament is a tweak to the backstop - putting the ball in Brussels court.CORBYN - MORE FUDGELast night Jeremy Corbyn and his frontbench allies tabled an amendment laying out Labours policy.The non-binding motion would see Britain seek to reopen the withdrawal agreement - something the EU insists is impossible.It also suggests that the Government should allow MPs to vote on whether or not to back a second referendum.BENN - NONSTOP VOTESSenior backbencher Hilary Benn wants ministers to stage a series of indicative votes on what to do next.That would allow MPs to have their say on their preferred outcome - from No Deal to a second referendum.CREASY - CITIZENS ASSEMBLYAn amendment from Labour Remainer Stella Creasy is a bid to secure a citizens assembly on Brexit.It would force the Government to delay Article , then convene an assembly of  representative voters to discuss the way forward.REEVES - STOP THE CLOCKLabours Rachel Reeves has drawn up an amendment which would simply delay BrexitBritain is heading towards a No Deal.Its a simplied version of the bill tabled by Yvette Cooper.SPELMAN DROMEY - NO DEAL  NO WAYTory ex-minister Caroline Spelman and Labours Jack Dromey want the Government to rule out No Deal.Their amendment would state that the Commons rejects the United Kingdom leaving the European Union without a withdrawal agreement and a framework for the future relationship.LIB DEMS - CANCEL BREXITVince Cable and his Lib Dem allies have put down a motion to force a second referendum on Brexit.The amendment says the Government should prepare for a People’s Vote in which the public will have the option to remain in the European Union.

title: annegret kramp karrenbauer irish backstop
story: Unlikely because it does not yet exist and requires a sharp change of attitude on all sides.But in times of crisis, ­anything is possible.Hardline Tory Brexiteers are now prepared to vote for ­Theresa May’s shattered EU Withdrawal Bill — as long as she ditches the wretched Northern Ireland backstop.Meanwhile, Germany is under siege from its political and industrial leaders, who are finally speaking out against a breach in trade and security ties with a vital European ally.Together this makes it ­possible to navigate a way through the thicket of bitterness and rancour which has soured ­politics, ided families and split the British nation.It requires a change of tack from Theresa May — never an easy ask.The PM’s deal is toxic because it hands Northern ­Ireland to Brussels as a ­province of the EU.Cutting out this tumour would win Mrs May the backing of at least  MPs, including Tory Brexiteers and the hardline DUP.Remainers would have ­little choice but to join in, giving Mrs May her majority and scuppering Jeremy ­Corbyn’s demands for a snap election.This might be seen as an impossible dream, not least because the hated backstop was allegedly invented in Downing Street, not Brussels.German negotiators pounced on an easy win.Now Berlin, the ultimate EU power broker, is facing fierce protests from industrialists over the risk to car, aerospace and engineering giantsBritain leaves with No Deal.“A hard Brexit would be disastrous,” says Dieter Kempf, head of Germany’s BDI — the equivalent of our Confederation of British Industry.“It would cause great dficulty for tens of thousands of companies and hundreds of thousands of workers on both sides.”Friday’s touching note from German politicians to The Times newspaper pleads with Britain to stay — or at least leave on friendly terms.But this is no love letter. It is hard-nosed realism.Signicantly, it bears the ­signature of Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, Angela Merkel’s chosen successor as Germany’s next Chancellor.Her appeal can be seen as a rebuke to Mrs Merkel, who rejected David Cameron’s plea for help to curb immigration, tipping ­Britain towards Brexit.Brits might have chosen dferentlyshe had responded to voters’ dismay not just in Britain but across the EU.She later signed her own political death warrant by flinging open Europe’s borders to a million Syrian migrants.But voters’ resentment towards arrogant EU leaders — recorded by their own Eurostat polling system — long predates immigration.Embattled French President Emmanuel Macron recently admitted he had dared not offer his voters a “Frexit”  ­referendum — because they would leave in a flash.Weeks later, his fears were confirmed as “yellow-vest” anarchists set Paris ablaze.French observers believe the gilets jaunes riots have their origins in another referendum crisis.In , France voted overwhelmingly against the European Constitution — only to see it renamed the Lisbon Treaty and slyly introduced against their express wishes.The European Constitution, like the disastrous euro, was a crucial but unpopular step towards a federal European superstate.Ireland and ­Denmark have also voted down EU moves to ever-closer union.They were told to vote again until they said Yes.Brussels’ arrogant contempt for ordinary voters — dismissed by one French president as “scum” — is what politicians blithely describe as the “democratic deficit”.It sowed the seeds for Brexit. Immigration simply brought it to a head.Germany’s letter to The Times reads like a plea from a deserted lover.“Without your great nation, this continent would not be what it is today — a community defined by freedom and ­prosperity,” writes Germany’s next Chancellor.“Should Britain wish to leave the European Union for good, it will always have friends in Germany and Europe.”This is precisely what British voters hoped for as they ­teetered on the brink of Remain but opted to Leave.They wanted a civilised orce between economic and diplomatic allies.This is still possiblethe border issue can be resolved.If we can persuade the IRA to decommission deadly weapons, surely we can decommission a backstop that nobody wants Theresa May’s rejected deal is not a total failure. Without this problem it could still fly.Germany holds the key.If Mrs Kramp-Karrenbauer means what she said about friendship, now is the time to prove it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the shocking ways people have tried to treat stis
story: And the historical ways of treating them are arguably worse, with infected people being subjected to hot irons to their bits and being forced to bathe in blood-sucking leeches.While STIs are often treated with medication as they are caused by bacteria and viruses passed on during sex, UK experts have expressed concern about new super-strains of the conditions that are resistant to all treatments.And without antibiotics - or when they dont work - people in the past have resorted to more extreme methods of getting rid of gruesome STIs, such as having lethal mercury rubbed on them and even having sex with virgins...Between the s and , French doctors were convinced they had found the best way of getting rid of the oozing pus in the genital area caused by gonorrhoea.Sufferers were smacked with hard books to try and coax the yellow goop out of their rectum.The ancient Romans believed the only way to get rid of genital herpes was to directly burn the infected flesh with a hot iron.A Greek doctor, Solanus of Ephesus, suggested that gonorrhoea was caused by a build-up of semen in the body, and prescribed lead weights strapped to the body for recovery.Just across the Mediterranean in Egypt, sufferers lay in agony while spells to drive away the demons they thought caused the illness were read out.They also used ointments made from herbs and garlic in an attempt to ease the pain.The ancient Egyptians cast spells and applied ointments made with garlic to genitaliaWhile we now know its highly-toxic to humans, mercury was used for centuries as a way to treat syphilis.This dangerous method cropped up as recently as the early s in Europe.An Italian doctor, Roger of Salerno, made two rather horric suggestions for STI treatments in the s.He recommended people should be bathed in a pool of blood-sucking leeches which he thought could slowly remove traces of the disease from the veins.His other option was urethral irrigation which would have involved a - probably unsterilised - object used to wash out the problem.Elsewhere in medieval Europe, doctors recommended patients be covered in sweating cloths first dipped in a liquid containing dangerous lead.Then, during the Renaissance, between  and , there was a widespread belief that having sex with a female virgin could treat you.Known as the virgin cure, men were wrongly convinced the purity of the woman would absolve them of the disease.In Italy in the s, it was thought sleeping with African women was the perfect antidote.By the s, as many as one in three diseased soldiers and sailors had an STI, and many Victorians were convinced the problem lay with prostitutes.The government passed laws allowing police to arrest, examine, detain, and treat women who they believed were selling sex.If found to be infected, these women were kept in a lock house - a hospital or workhouse - to sit out their symptoms, or thrown in jail for up to a year.Poor people with STIs were refused treatment at charitable hospitals, and were left dependent on donations and benefactors, as society still felt venereal diseases were a punishment for past vice.The upper classes in the nineteenth century still didnt have great solutions, though, and some were more than their le was worth.This included fumigation, where the sufferer was exposed to - now known to be toxic - vapours fused with mercury or silver nitrate.Doctors would often apply too high a dose and accidentally kill their patients.It was several decades before penicillin came on the scene in  as an effective cure for early syphilis.However, attitudes that STIs were the fault of women - and not men - prevailed, and in the same year images at army bases showed the mugshots of women who had tested positive displayed on a board.It was another century before antibiotics and antiviral drugs were introduced to blitz STIs - but with them on the increase in the UK we could soon have to look to other options to banish the bugs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit len mccluskey blasts theresa
story: NewsBrexit: Len McCluskey blasts Theresa May for two wasted years as she meets him at NoThe Unite boss finally walked through that famous black door more than two years after she took office - but warned talks could be a "PR stunt"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video watch-len-mccluskey-speaks-media-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLen McCluskey has blasted Theresa May for two wasted years after she met him for historic union talks at  Downing Street.The Unite boss made his first trip to No under Mrs Mays leadership as she made a pitch to safeguard workers rights after Brexit .Trades Union Congress chief Frances OGrady, Unison general secretary Dave Prentis and Tim Roache of the GMB also had one-on-one talks. But as he exited the famous black front door, Mr McCluskey warned the talks could be a PR stunt - and urged the Prime Minister to delay Brexit to prevent a disastrous No Deal. What I was saying to the PM was look, is this just a PR stunt for the media, for you to say youve consulted with trade union officials  he said.  Or is this a genuine attempt to seewe can talk about issues that matter to us  He added: Its probably two and a half years too late. I wish wed been involved in the discussions way back then.Britains biggest union boss rebuffed calls from cross-party MPs for Labour to swing behind a second EU referendum. Instead he said the date of Brexit should be delayed, for around three months,proper further negotiations can be held. He also backed Jeremy Corbyns decision not to attend talks with Mrs May about the way forward. And he urged MPs to back an amendment by Labour, due for a vote on Tuesday, which would spell out several options for what to do next.  Weve been placed in this current mess, I think two years has been wasted with the PM having to argue with her own party, he said. Now were in this dire position and Labour have put down an amendment that gets us out of it.  Speaking earlier, TUC general secretary Frances OGrady warned she had not received the guarantees unions are seeking on jobs and workers rights.And she repeated her call for Theresa May to take a no-deal Brexit off the table as she emerged from Downing Street. The Prime Minister was meeting union bosses just as one of Britains largest manufacturers, Airbus, issued a stark warning of the potential damage to jobs from a no-deal departure. The aerospace giants chief executive, Tom Enders, branded the Governments handling of EU withdrawal a disgrace and warned the company could pull out of the UKBrexit undermines its ability to compete.  Chancellor Philip Hammond was preparing to tell leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos that post-Brexit Britain will still be a great place to do business. But Mr Enders said the UKs multi-billion pound aerospace sector was standing at a precipice. Brexit is threatening to destroy a century of development based on education, research and human capital, he said.  If theres a no-deal Brexit, we at Airbus will have to make potentially very harmful decisions for the UK. Speaking after talks in Downing Street, Ms OGrady said: The Prime Minister should do the right thing and take a no deal off the table so that genuine dialogue can take place.

title: brexit plan b explained amendments
story: NewsBrexit Plan B explained: Amendments to Theresa Mays deal and what they meanBrexits a smouldering wreck with barely two months to go. Here are the Plan Bs that are emerging, how MPs could take back control - and how the Queen could get dragged inShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan Bloom:,  JAN NewsMPs are planning to take control of the process "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit is a smouldering wreck after Theresa Mays deal suffered the worst defeat in House of Commons history. But out of the ashes, a string of radically dferent Plan B options are taking shape - and will wrestle for control in the Commons. The Prime Ministers own Plan B will go head to head with plans from Remain-backing MPs that could delay Brexit or stop it altogether. Labour wants to leave with a customs union, while other Remainers want to force a second EU referendum. Importantly, MPs will hold a vote on some of these options at pm on Tuesday  January - giving Theresa May a mandate toto the EU. So what are the biggest amendments that have been proposed so far and what will they do  Heres our rolling guide, which well continue to update as the vote draws near. The key plans Theresa Mays Plan B: Rework the Irish backstop and go back to EU in February  Theresa May ed to MPs on Monday  January to outline her own Plan B. She suggested she simply wants to tweak her -page Brexit deal - including a backstop that could trap the UK under EU customs rules - instead of ripping the whole thing up. The PM did not categorically rule out the customs union demanded by Labour - or, crucially, extending the  March date of Brexit. But she tried to rebuff calls for a customs union, a second referendum, ruling out No Deal, or revoking or extending the  March date of Brexit. Mrs May said she will continue with further meetings this week and consult this House on its negotiating mandate before ing to the EU to try and agree a further Plan B. She also offered confidential briefings to MPs on the way forward, guarantees on workers rights, and consultation with parliaments committees. Yet key figures in the EU savaged Mrs Mays Plan B pleas as party politics. And Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn told MPs: The Prime Ministers invitation to talks has been exposed as a PR sham. Contrary to what the Prime Minister just said there was no flexibility, there were no negotiations - nothing hadchanged. WILL IT SUCCEED  Unlikely. Itd need to EU to reopen talks on the backstop - a red line for Brussels. Itd also need around  Tory Brexiteers to cave in and decide Mays deal is the only way to prevent Brexit being stopped.  The key amendment would force Theresa May try to delay the  March date of Brexit - and take No Deal off the table. It is being led by Labour MP Yvette Cooper and Tory MP Nick Boles, both Remain-backers. And crucially it appears it will be backed by the Labour frontbench and Jeremy Corbyn - giving it enough support to pass. The amendment would allow MPs to vote on a motion directing Mrs May to request an extension of the Article  date from EU chiefs,there is no new deal by February . Officially No are against the amendment, but Remain-backing ministers secretly support it because it will allow her to delay Brexit without getting her hands dirty. Ms Cooper, who chairs the Commons Home Affairs Committee, said: I think sheknows that she should rule out no deal in the national interest because it would be so damaging. Shes refusing to do so and I think shes hoping that Parliament will do this for her - that is not leadership. WILL IT SUCCEED  It has a very good chance. Tory Remainers Oliver Letwin and Nicky Morgan already back the bid, and now it looks like the Labour frontbench will join in, it has a reasonable prospect of passing. Jeremy Corbyns party has tabled an amendment which calls for Parliament to have a say on all the options. Theyd include Labours own Brexit plan - a Norway plus style agreement - and also the option for a second referendum. Party sources say the amendment is in line with the partys conference motion, which called for all options to be on the table. Labour believes its version of Brexit which would include a permanent customs union, relationship with the single market and alignment on rights and standards could get a Commons majority. But a growing number of Labour MPs want a second vote - and more than % of the partys membership also back another poll. Peoples Vote supporters hailed the amendment as a major step forward to a public ballot. But shadow minister Rebecca Long-Bailey denied it made a second referendum much more likely. Jeremy Corbyn said: Our amendment will allow MPs to voteon options to end this Brexit deadlock and prevent the chaos of a No Deal. WILL IT SUCCEED  Unlikely. Tory Remainers signalled early on they would not side with Labours motion.   Former Attorney General Dominic Grieve had proposed a radical plan to let backbenchers take control of the Commons timetable - MPs, including five parties and  Tories, backed the proposal. But this was controversial because itd allow MPs to seize the timetable without a majority. No branded it a coup. And its since been watered down. A much less exciting version of Mr Grieves plan now outlines plans to let MPs take control of parliamentary business one day each fortnight between now and March . It is backed by MPs from across Parliament, including fellow Tories like ex-ministers Justine Greening and Sam Gymiah, plus Phillip Lee, Anna Soubry and Sarah Wollaston. For Labour, those signed up include Chris Bryant, Chris Leslie, Chuka Umunna and Ben Bradshaw while Lib Dem Brexit spokesman Tom Brake and Green MP Caroline Lucas are also signatories. The amendment states that on February  and , and March , ,  and , the first item of business in the Commons would be a Motion in the name of the Chairman of Ways and Means That this House has considered the United Kingdoms departure from, and future relationship with, the European Union. Tory MP Anna Soubry said she will back a combination of the Cooper and Grieve plans, because put together, they can ensure No Deal is blocked and Parliament takes back control. WILL IT SUCCEED  It seems more likely now the most alarming elements have been removed. But its still a slight unknown. Hilary Benn: Let MPs choose between four ways forward  A separate amendment by Hilary Benn, chairman of the Commons Brexit Committee, would give MPs indicative votes on the way forward. MPs would choose from dferent options to see which would come out on top. They are:Another vote on Theresa Mays deal A No Deal Brexit Renegotiate the deal with EU to achieve a specic outcome A second EU referendumWILL IT SUCCEED  Its chances of success are not yet clear. Andrew Murrison: Demand an expiry date on the Irish backstop  Tory MP Andrew Murrison tabled a short and sweet amendment to set an expiry date on the Northern Ireland backstop. He claimed it could help get Theresa Mays deal over the line by appealing to moderate MPs who just want Brexit sorted. But the EU has repeatedly ruled out putting an expiry date on the backstop. Brussels says the entire point of the clause is its an insurance policy forthe worst happens, so it wont workit has an end date. WILL IT SUCCEED  Not in the long run. It could win over some Tory MPs. Butit passes it would then create a huge headache in talks with the EU. MPs pulled a straight vote on a second EU referendum after confessing it would not have enough support in the House of Commons. The cross-party group had wanted MPs to vote on an amendment calling for a new public referendum. But five days before the vote they announced they will not table the amendment - admitting not enough MPs support it. The group, including Labours Chuka Umunna and Chris Leslie, blamed Jeremy Corbyn - saying he should do the right thing and give unequivocal backing to a second referendum to ensure it can pass. Tory MP Sarah Wollaston said: We could have the numberswe had the unequivocal backing of Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour leadership. I think that is where we will get to eventually.   Plans with less chance of success John Baron: No Irish backstop The Tory MP goes further than his colleague Andrew Murrisonand seeks to rule out an Irish backstop completely. His amendment seeks to avoid any arrangement at the Irish border that would tie any part of the UK to EU customs rules until a formal trade deal was in place. Needless to say the EU wont accept this. And Mr Baron tried to pass a similar amendment before which failed by a landslide. Stella Creasy: Delay Brexit and let a Citizens Assembly take charge Labour MP Stella Creasy has proposed forcing the government to delay Brexit, with EU permission, and set up a Citizens Assembly. This new body would have a representative sample of  people to consider next steps. With help from the supergroup Liaison Committee, this Assembly would make recommendations to the House of Commons within  weeks. The government would have to respond within two weeks and set out how it will ensure the recommendations can be implemented in full.Rachel Reeves: Delay Brexit Rachel Reeves, the Labour MP, also has an amendment to extend the March  date of Brexittheres no agreement by the end of February. Again, this would need the EUs approval. Frank Field: Indicative votes The former Labour MP has joined forces with Tory Ed Vaizey to give MPs a say on a iety of options. Their amendment would mean the Commons would have to allow time for a series of votes to act as a powerful guide to the government. The options would include:Reforming the Northern Ireland backstop Leaving the EU without a deal Delaying the UKs exit from the EU Canada-style future relationship Norway-style future relationship Customs union Holding a new referendumCaroline Spelman: Prevent no deal The cross-party amendment, which also has the support of Jack Dromey, Heidi Allen, Dr Sarah Wollaston and Anna Soubry, attempts to simply reject the UK leaving without a deal. Tom Brake: cross-party committee The Liberal Democrats amendment would create a cross-party committee to take charge of the Brexit process. It would have power to decide when parliamentary time should be made available for Brexit debates and legislation, including on a fresh referendum with Remain on the ballot paper, to appoint special advisers, and to travel within the UK and to Brussels. Vince Cable: Call for a second referendum The Lib Dem leader wants to “instruct the Government to take all necessary steps to rule out a no-deal scenario and prepare for a People’s Vote in which the public will have the option to remain in the European Union on the ballot paper. Plus - how the Queen could get dragged in   Theresa May could drag the Queen into a showdown with Parliament,MPs try to cancel or postpone Brexit. Former top government lawyer Sir Stephen Laws said trying to change the law in this way through an amendment, without the Government’s participation, could create a constitutional crisis. In a paper for the Policy Exchange think tank, Sir Stephen said: “It could raise a question whether the Government would be entitled or might feel required to reassert its constitutional veto by advising the Queen not to grant Royal Assent to the Bill. “How should the Monarch react to such advice  The answer is not straightforward and the prospect of it needing to be considered in a real le political crisis is unthinkably awful. “It is a sacred duty of all UK politicians not to involve the Monarch in politics. They have a constitutional responsibility to resolve dficulties between themselves in accordance with the rules, and so as not to call on the ultimate referee.”

title: brexit whsmith stockpiles six months
story: NewsBrexit: WHSmith stockpiles six months of pens and notebooksThe stationers, who source most of their products from Asia, normally hold between three and four months worth of pens and notepadsShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsWHSmith want to avoid disruptions to the supply of stationery "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email WHSmith have said they are stockpiling six months worth of pens to guard against chaos at the border caused by Brexit .The stationers, who source most of their products from Asia, normally hold between three and four months worth of pens, diaries and notepads. But the boss of the British firm confirmed they were planning to hold six months worth to avoid disruptions to their supplies. Stephen Clarke, WHSmith’s chief executive, told Bloomberg: We’re used to holding quite a bit of forward cover in terms of stock anyway, so what we’ve done is topped that up a little bit to put ourselves in an even better position should there be congestion at ports. It is one of many firms making preparations ahead of the UKs exit on March .  High end clothing firm Joules is setting up a third-party warehouse on the continent which will serve wholesale customers in the EU. It has also arranged for early delivery of its spring-summer collection and increased its foreign currency holdings to protect it from a potentially volatile poind. While luxury fashion house Burberry warned that a no-deal Brexit would be ‘complex’ and could cost the firm tens of millions of pounds in added expenses. Julie Brown, finance chief at the FTSE  company said that crashing out of the EU without a deal ‘would be complex to manage’. In a trading update to the City yesterday she added: The biggest concern is the disruption to the supply chain.

title: brexit you might renew your
story: NewsBrexit: Why you might have to renew your passport  MONTHS earlyFor most people, the advice is to renew your passport six months before it expires. Butyour passport was valid for more than  years, the rules are very dferentShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN NewsFor most people, the advice is to renew your passport six months before it expires "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSome Brits will have to renew their passports  MONTHS earlythere is a No Deal Brexit. The government has revealed a little-known loophole that could bar families from holiday hotspots like France and Spain this summer. Since last year, Brits have been warned to have at least six months left on their passportthey want to travel to the EU in a No-Deal. But now officials admit some people will need to renew much earlier than that. Its because between  and September , some UK passports were issued with more than  years lespan. Yet those extra months - awarded when people carried over time from their old passport - wont countyou are entering the EU.  Soyou have a passport that is valid for longer than  years, you should not just count six months back from the expiry date to find out when it wont be valid. Instead you should count  years and six months forward from the date it was issued to find out when itll no longer be valid in the EU. Before the scheme ended in , Brits were able to get up to nine months added to the usual -year lespan of their passport.That means, as a maximum, some people will have to renew their passports  months early - nine months that dont count in the EU, plus another six months before the expiry date. Government guidance explains: Since , some adult British passports were issued with a validity longer than  years.If you renewed your passport before it expired, you were allowed to have the time left on your old passport added to your new passport.The maximum validity period possible was  years and  months.  This means you can’t use the expiry date to checkyour adult passport will be valid under the new rules. These rules will only applyBritain leaves the EU on March  without a Brexit deal. That is looking less likely as MPs plot to delay the date of Brexit. But the fact remains that, with just  days to go, the UK has still not agreed any final Brexit deal with the EU. So as it stands, these rules would kick in at pm on Friday  March. Read our full guide to when you should renew your passport here.

title: johnny mercer pays back almost
story: NewsJohnny Mercer pays back almost £, after expenses probe into Tory MPA watchdog said there was no evidence to claims the MP was "electioneering" - but did tell him to repay £ShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  JAN NewsJohnny Mercer said the increased cost was due to his phone system being “hacked” and used to make phone calls to Albania "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory MP Johnny Mercer has been ordered to pay back almost pound, in expenses after an investigation into his phone bills. A complainant accused Mr Mercer of using taxpayers’ money for “electioneering” after his constituency office phone bills went up from an average pound a month to pound in March , just before the local elections. But Mr Mercer denied the lines were used for canvassing said the increased cost was due to his phone system being “hacked” and used to make phone calls to Albania. Following a probe, MPs expenses watchdog IPSA found absolutely no evidence to find the breaches were anything other than genuine oversights. However, Mr Mercer was told to repay pound. to the watchdog, which he has now paid back.  Those sums included:pound due to increased phone bills in March  as a result of Mr Mercers phone network being hacked. pound. for submitting the April  phone bill later, in September . pound. in relation to a duplicate claim for a phone bill in January .A complaint to MPs expenses watchdog IPSA also questioned why Mr Mercer had six phone lines installed in his office, when he does not have that many staff. Mr Mercer told IPSA he made an assessment that six lines would be necessary when he was first elected, but the report says “he realises that in reality he probably only needs four.” The IPSA report said: “There were around  callsto the same Albanian number on the th and early hours on the st of March. “There is insufficient information to determine the purpose of these calls, but it is certainly unusual and we suggest there may be merit in including these as part of an investigation into high telephony costs”.” IPSA said there was “absolutely no evidence to suggest any of the breaches are anything other than genuine oversights which could have been avoided with better administration and supervision.” The watchdog did not uphold a series of claims surrounding Mr Mercer’s website. Questions were raised about why Mr Mercer had claimed for several domain names, which include “johnnyforplymouth”, “Johnnyforplymouth”, “Johnnymercermp.uk”, “Johnnymercermp”, “and Johnnymercermp”. Mr Mercer told IPSA he bought the domains, at a cost to the taxpayer of more than pound, to prevent others setting up “duplicate sites”. IPSA said: “It could be argued that this may not be a good use of taxpayers’ money, but it is not technically against the Scheme.”   The watchdog also investigated the cost of setting up Mr Mercer’s website, which ran to pound,, and was set up by a firm called Smallporate, run by the husband of a member of his staff and based in the same building as his constituency office. Their report reveals invoices relating to setting up the site “lacked detail and transparency in relation to the web designer.” The complainant said it was “excessive and not value for money.” But IPSA did not uphold the complaint. Mr Mercer told IPSA: “I just looked at what I was looking for, what the market value of those things were, how I could get value for money for the tax payer, have a professional operation as a Member of Parliament and then I made the decision to go to Smallporate and build the website”. He added: “In terms of nepotism or favouritism or anything like that, people like me are acutely aware of that, but the reality isyou have the best person for the job, the fact that they are your friends we is irrelevant, it’s irrelevant because it’s all about service to the people who voted for me and the people who pay those wages and that is the tax payer.” Mr Mercer repaid pound. to IPSA in respect of the phone bill costs.

title: theresa pathetically insults jeremy corbyn
story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire: Theresa May insults Jeremy Corbyn instead of answering his questionsMays my way or no way approach gets peoples backs upShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinionthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video dodges-questions-corbyn-manages-hold-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOh how Theresa May was at her patronising, self-righteous, evasive worst at Prime Ministers Questions with a woeful performance. Pathetically insulting Jeremy Corbyn instead of replying honestly to his pertinent inquiries illustrated why thin-skinned of Downing Streets proved such a poor negotiator. Unable to engage positively and resenting accountability, Mays my way or no way approach gets peoples backs up. It was Corbyn who sounded reasonable on Brexit and Mays wriggling was the squirming of a PM losing control. The Labour leaders right that her door might be open but her minds closed - a line he nicked from Hilary Benn that Corbyn liked so much he used it twice.  I was surprised he didnt raise Brexit boss James Dysons Singapore dash, PO registering ferries in Cyprus or Sony abandoning Britain for Holland. But voters watching at home wouldve seen and heard a calm Corbyn and a rattled, desperate May. To coin her most infamous phrase: Nothing has changed.

story: NewsTony Blair defends posing with far-right Brazilian leader Jair BolsonaroThe former PM was slammed for the snap in Swiss resort Davos - but he hit back by slamming Twitter users who "only speak to people they already agree with"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsTony Blair was approached by Jair Bolsonaro at the World Economic Forum in Davos"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTony Blair has defended his decision to pose for a photo with the far-right new President of Brazil. The former Prime Minister sparked fury after the picture of him with Jair Bolsonaro emerged from the World Economic Forum in Davos. The snap provoked anger among online commentators who branded it utterly inexcusable and branded Bolsonaro a neofascist thug.Labour MP Chris Williamson tweeted: Bolsonaros domestic agenda for Brazil and his plans for environmental degradation should make him an international pariah. Left-wing columnist Owen Jones added:Tony Blair does PR stunts with racist gay hating fascist Bolsonaro, when will his last apologists stop defending him, and when will he be expelled from the Labour Party. But Mr Blair hit back today in a statement attacking pundits who only speak to people who already agree with you on Twitter .  A spokesman for Mr Blair told the Mirror: It is possible to be civil towards someone who does not share your world view, dialogue is important. Unless you think you should only speak to people who already agree with you on Twitter. The spokesman said there was no formal or pre-arranged meeting between Mr Blair and Bolsonaro at the elite Swiss gathering. He added: They were both in an open space and President Bolsonaro simply walked up and introduced himself and asked his photographer to take a picture. This all took place in under a minute.  Bolsonaro was sworn in on January  as Brazils first far-right President since a military dictatorship ended three decades ago. The ex-army officer dubbed the Trump of the Tropics has previously been charged with inciting hatred by Brazils attorney general. He also he would be incapable of loving a gay son, and once told a congresswoman: I wouldnt rape you because youre not worthy of it. The number of gay marriages in Brazil reportedly surged % in November as LGBT people fear a crackdown on their rights. And his plans to build hydroelectric dams in the Amazon and open up to mining the reservations of indigenous peoples have sparked alarm. But he rode a wave of anti-establishment anger to gain % of the votes in Octobers election, promising to crack down on corruption and violent crime.

story: NewsDrink-driving businesswoman, , used white wine to cope with menopauseAngela Rose-Gorrell, , was caught drunk at the wheel of her Lexus on the M, magistrates in Manchester were toldShareCommentsByHayley Sewell:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAngela Rose-Gorrell has been banned from the roads for drink-driving "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA drink-driving businesswoman says she was downing white wine to cope with going through the menopause. Angela Rose-Gorrell was caught drunk at the wheel of her luxury Lexus on the M in December, a court heard.The -year-old was made to perform a breath test which showed she was almost three times the legal booze limit, reports the Manchester Evening News.Rose-Gorrell, who runs a recruitment firm in Preston, later said she had suffered anxiety and panic attacks while going through the menopause for  months and would drink alcohol to calm down. The mum-of-one, who lives in Buckshaw village near Chorley, has since given up drinking and is utterly mortied to have wound up in court,Manchesters magistrateswere told.  On Tuesday, Rose-Gorrell admitted driving with excess alcohol and was fined pound,, plus pound costs and surcharges. She was also disqualied from driving for  months. She said her business and marriage would suffershe was banned from the road, and would not be able to drive her son to school four miles away. The court heard the incident occurred on December , last year, after Rose-Gorrell had cancelled a business meeting following what she described as a stressful morning. Whilst working from home she drank some wine and was arrested later as she pulled into Rivington Services off the northbound carriageway, the court heard. Prosecutor Martin Brogan said: A police officer was on duty and received messages regarding a motor vehicle on the M. The officer pulled the car over and asked them to stop in a service station. The officer spoke to the defendant and could smell intoxicant on her breath.   They asked her to perform a Breathalyser test, which they had some issues with but the officer felt there was sufficient alcohol on her breath. She was taken to the police station. She has no previous convictions. Tests showed Rose-Gorrell had  micrograms of alcohol in  millilitres of breath. The legal limit is mg. Sarah Gruffydd, defending, told the bench: She is utterly mortied and ashamed to be here. She is  and has been in no trouble whatsoever. What happened behind this,  months ago she began finding it dficult to manage her stress and was having panic attacks - she soon found out these were symptoms of the menopause. She did not speak to people but started drinking wine to calm down. On th December she had had a stressful morning and was suffering with anxiety. She cancelled a meeting she was due to have for work and worked from home whilst having some wine. She made the foolish decision to drive thereafter, and as a result of that decision, she has caused consequences to her family.   She has a  year old son who attends school four miles away and drives him there. She is struggling to work out how to get him there with no buses in the area. For  years she has run a business with her husband, building up a reputation for the company. Her role is to meet clients and secure projects for her husband in the north west. She is now limited in the role and her husband is in turn limited in his role, meaning the business is going to suffer. This has caused huge problems within their marriage. She in no way underestimates the seriousness of what she has done. She feels very ashamed and it has been a scare for her. She has said she will not drink ever again and has been to the doctor about her menopause and stress symptoms. She is now on medication and feeling much better for it. Sentencing, chairman of the bench Jane Whittington rejected the prosecutions suggestions for a community penalty and said: We are going to give you a fine as we believe you have tried to help yourself. Keep payments up and do not drive.
